attributes.description: Deities of particular class with five or ten enumerated, worshipped at funeral obsequies for deceased progenitors
God to whom Ráma paid right/due at new cottage
God to whom Ráma paid right/due, Chitrakúta holiest spot for sect devoted to this incarnation
Father who calls Gods to glorious council hall, creator
Celestial beings who assemble at Brahmá's call, advance in shining train
Heavenly Twins, bright, seek woods beneath Mandar's peak, compared to Ráma and Lakshmana
Lord of death, Kausalyá threatens to sink to his realms below
Lord Mahendra whose standard compared to Ráma's fair form
Prince of mighty arm and chest, godlike one, illustrious, duteous, joy and stay, strong-armed hero, Raghu's son, wielder of mighty bow, shoulders like lion
Faithful brother, Sumitrá's son, eager mind inclined to brother's will, bright-eyed, swift performer, glorious, walked ahead to guard path
Ráma's wife, Janak's daughter, Videhan bride/lady, votaress who heaved sigh, noble princess, tender, soft, fair, delicate, large-eyed, moonlike beauty
King, monarch, old man, lord of earth, sovereign, stricken in years, sire of high renown, weeping, forlorn, pale, faint, sorrow-worn, distressed
Queen, Ráma's mother, most excellent of beauteous dames, trembling, lying prostrate, wailing, sore distressed, weeping
Queen cruel, false, of evil race, evil bred, gave light charge, wretch who received boon
Queen, mother of Lakshmana, aided Kausalyá in raising king
Young prince, strong-armed chief, brings joy to Ikshváku's line, regent heir, to be loved and honored
Ancient anchoret, great saint in duty trained, met in woodland dwelling, gave welcome fair
Charioteer, faithful, best of peers, sad mien, flooded eye, dust on limbs, suppliant hands, reverent
King whose heart sank with sorrow when Ráma reached southern bank, talked with Sumantra
Person whose words are dread monsters in sea of sorrow metaphor
Ancient figure expelled from skies who held sweet converse with saints
Holy mountain with creepers, trees, fruit and roots, pleasant life offered, lovely hill with lily-covered rill, holiest spot for Vishnu devotees
Cot built by Lakshmana with timber from wood, firmly built, roofed with leaves, fair to see, well-set, fenced from wind and rain
River, Gangá's shore where Sumantra left princes, farther shore they crossed
Place where steps bent after crossing Gangá
Royal city, town silent and forsaken, drowned in sorrow, empty grove and garden, burnt with grief, mourning like queen for son
Wild woods where Kausalyá wants to be placed, forest shade, wilderness
Mountain beneath whose peak woods hang where Ashvins seek
Sacrifice paid for lengthened life with antelope venison, as Scripture bids, verses repeated to make complete
Ritual with muttered prayer, water, grass, wood, fire, offerings to Gods and shades, bathed duly in river, good offerings remove sin
Many built to suit holy shade, decked with woodland chaplets, fruit, roots, roasted meat
Joining hands, head bent, greeting sent to father's feet, mother's blessing, honor to king like Gods, duty to monarchs paramount
Soul on fire, breathing fast words of ire, king is cause/poor slave, questioned king's authority, ties loosed
Locks wound in votive fashion, coats of bark bound
Trees hang low, shoot/bud/flower dead, floods dried, groves drear, beasts still, serpents don't crawl, lethargy of woe, blossoms lost scent
Elaborate metaphor: sorrow raging sea, Ráma's absence swells tide, Sítá's absence makes wide, tears foam, sighs billows, cries roar, Kaikeyí fire beneath
Persuasive art, soothing fancies, pleasant words to cheer, conduct buys wide glory
Cannot live single hour without them, needs must go to forest or Yama's realm, shrill lament 'My son, my son!'
Ráma, Lakshmana, Sítá spoke raising suppliant hands to anchoret, requested to stay, saint entertained with honor
Lakshmana brought timber, built leafy hut deftly with branches, firmly built and walled with wood
Sacrifice paid with antelope venison, Lakshmana shot deer, meat broiled, sacred rites begun, Ráma repeated verses, celestial hosts came
Paid Vishvedevas, Rudra, Vishnu due, wonted blessings, made altars and shrines, entered pleasant cot, forgot exile's woe
Guha's heart sank, spent with sorrow, yoked steeds, sped to Ayodhyá, third day reached gate, city drowned in sorrow
Hundreds/thousands ran crying 'Where is Ráma?', drew deep sighs, wailed, tears fell when knew he crossed flood
Sumantra through seven courts, royal ladies flocked from terraces, heard them mourn for Ráma, reached monarch's hall
King heard message, heart well-nigh broke, fainting fell to earth, senses astray, overcome by grief
With Sumitrá raised lord dismayed, cried to him, lay prostrate, voice drowned by sobs, flocked around and wept
Sumantra told greeting to father's feet, mother's blessing, honor king like Gods, message to Bharat, Lakshmana's angry words
Locks in votive coils, bark coats, crossed Gangá, went to Prayág, Lakshmana walked ahead, forced to return

attributes.context: Realms mourn, trees withering, floods dried, groves drear, beasts still, wood silent, crushed with grief

attributes.description: King cried elaborate metaphor comparing grief to raging sea with multiple elements, sank on bed, spirit failed, senses fled
Trembling, lying prostrate, half awoke, begged to be borne to forest or Yama's realm, no power to linger
Choked by tears, suppliant hands, urged dismiss grief, described Sítá's contentment, Ráma's protection, conduct buys glory

attributes.context: Ráma spoke raising suppliant hands to anchoret, requested to stay on holy mountain
Lakshmana with Ráma and Sítá spoke to saint in woodland dwelling
Sítá raised suppliant hands with princes to ancient anchoret
Great saint in duty trained entertained with honor, gave welcome fair, bade rest
Anchoret met in woodland dwelling on holy mountain
Sumitrá's son obeyed, brought timber from wood, deftly made leafy hut
Ráma commanded brother to build cot beneath mountain with water supply
Ráma commanded sacrifice, repeated verses, paid Vishvedevas/Rudra/Vishnu due
Lakshmana shot deer, prepared venison, laid in kindled flame, meat broiled
Sítá with Ráma and Lakshmana paid offerings to each God and shade
Ráma paid Vishvedevas due at cottage consecration
Ráma paid Rudra's right at new cottage
Ráma paid Vishnu's right, Chitrakúta holiest for this incarnation
Gods assemble at Father Brahmá's call to glorious council hall
Ráma and Lakshmana compared to bright Heavenly Twins seeking woods beneath Mandar
Ráma's fair form compared to Lord Mahendra's standard
Ráma entered pleasant cot, resting on lovely hill forgot exile's woe
Lakshmana entered well-set cottage with Ráma and Sítá
Sítá entered pleasant cot, illustrious three like Gods to council hall
Ráma resting on lovely hill near lily-covered rill, forgot exile's lot
Ráma entered pleasant cot roofed with leaves, fenced from wind and rain
Charioteer yoked steeds, sped to Ayodhyá, third day reached gate
King Guha's heart sank with sorrow, talked with Sumantra, spent with sorrow homeward went
Charioteer came to city's gate, found town drowned in sorrow
Sumantra bore prince to Gangá's shore, left at his behest
After Gangá to Prayág steps were bent
Hundreds/thousands ran crying 'Where is Ráma?', wailed, tears fell
Charioteer said bore prince to Gangá's shore, left at behest
People in royal way wept bitter tears, looked for Ráma in vain
Charioteer through seven courts, heard royal ladies mourn, reached monarch's hall
Sovereign in palace bright, weeping for son, pale, faint, sorrow-worn
Ladies flocked from terraces wild with woe, talked in gentle tone moaning for Ráma
King heard message, heart well-nigh broke, fainting fell, overcome by grief for Ráma
Charioteer did obeisance reverent, repeated message Ráma bore
Queen with Sumitrá's aid raised lord dismayed, cried to him
Queen aided Kausalyá in raising king from ground
Ráma joining hands head bent sent greeting to father's feet, mother's blessing
Charioteer urged to speak, told words Ráma said with tears breaking utterance
Brother with soul on fire spoke breathing fast words of ire against king
Ráma sent message to Bharat: pray health bless life, love/care every queen, rule as regent
Ráma sent greeting to father's feet, resolved in duty's path to tread
Ráma sent greeting to mother, ne'er may steps from duty err
Ráma is Sítá's joy and stay, all heart no sorrow bends, life depends on him
Lakshmana walked ahead to guard path, eager mind inclined to brother's will
Sítá gives all heart to Ráma, free from doubt and terror, if not see him Ayodhyá like wood
Queen raised lord dismayed, addressed husband king
Mother cannot live single hour bereft of son, shrill lament 'My son!'
Queen urged king to speak freely, Kaikeyí stands not near of whom afraid
Locks in votive coils, bark coats bound, crossed Gangá to Prayág
Lakshmana walked ahead to guard path two should tread
Sítá with locks in votive coils and bark coat crossed Gangá
Realms mourn, each tree hangs low head, floods dried, groves drear, wood silent
Crushed with grief for Ráma all hushed, blossoms lost scent
King cried metaphor: sorrow raging sea, Ráma's absence swells tide, sank on bed, spirit failed
Sorrow for Ráma swells tide, till banishment be o'er
Sítá's absence makes sea of sorrow wide
Kaikeyí is fire that feeds beneath sea of sorrow
Hump-back's words are dread monsters in sea
Queen trembling, lying prostrate, half awoke, begged to be borne to forest or Yama's realm
Charioteer asked to bear her to Dandaka forest where Ráma/Sítá/Lakshmana are
Queen threatened to sink to Yama's realms below if cannot go to forest
Charioteer choked by tears, suppliant hands, persuasive art to turn from grief
Queen urged to dismiss grief, but still gave sorrow vent with shrill lament
Sumantra described Sítá's contentment, no sign of care, moonlike beauty suffers not
Ráma in wild as well as dear home dwells, exile in forest shade
King in palace bright, weeping for son, city mourns
Queen in city, wants to be borne to Dandaka forest
